item.title: Israel, Hamas Trade Accusations of Cease-Fire Violations
item.description: Hamas said several Gaza residents were killed by the Israeli military, while families of deceased hostages whose bodies are still in the enclave expressed anger at delays to their repatriation.
item.dc:creator: Anat Peled

item.title: Spain’s Grid Operator Denies Risk of Imminent Power Blackout After Sharp Voltage Swings
item.description: Red Electrica said sharp voltage swings detected in recent weeks were not a risk to the supply of electricity because they didn’t surpass acceptable limits.
item.dc:creator: Cristina Gallardo

item.title: China Adds Hanwha Ocean’s Units to Sanctions List
item.description: The Chinese commerce ministry has banned Chinese entities and individuals from working with five companies affiliated with South Korean shipbuilder Hanwha Ocean.
item.dc:creator: Kwanwoo Jun

item.title: China’s Rare-Earth Export Controls Are Critical Concern for EU, Trade Chief Says
item.description: Maros Sefcovic said the measures were causing a lot of problems for European companies, as tensions continue to rise between Brussels and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: Thyssenkrupp’s Warship Arm to List Next Week as Group Eyes European Defense Cash
item.description: TKMS is to start trading on the German stock exchange on Oct. 20, concluding the spinoff of a minority stake of the company.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: How China and the U.S. Are Racing to De-Escalate the Trade War
item.description: President Trump is trying to publicly ease tensions with China to soothe markets while privately keeping up pressure on Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Gavin Bade

item.title: Can Shotguns, Spy Planes and Lasers Protect Europe From the Next Drone Incursion?
item.description: A spate of suspected Russian drone appearances across Europe has forced countries to look for novel ways to protect their airspace.
item.dc:creator: Karolina Jeznach

item.title: Trump’s Big Gamble on Tackling the Middle East’s Intractable Problems
item.description: After the Gaza cease-fire, the president is aiming for a broader peace in a region transformed by two years of fighting.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Dowell

item.title: Opinion | Cuba’s José Daniel Ferrer Makes It To Miami
item.description: The dissident says he’s going into exile with his honor intact, ‘and not for long.’
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | Europe Joins the Steel Tariff Game
item.description: Brussels imposes border taxes to offset the cost of climate obsessions.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | Trump’s Hostage Triumph in Jerusalem
item.description: Israel won the war. Now the challenge, especially for the Arab and Muslim countries, is to ensure that Hamas loses the peace.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | Trump’s Triumphal March
item.description: But the core cause of the conflict hasn’t been and perhaps can’t be resolved.
item.dc:creator: Walter Russell Mead

item.title: Opinion | The Navy at 250 Faces New Challenges
item.description: As U.S. shipbuilding wanes, China’s sea power multiplies.
item.dc:creator: Kate Farmer

item.title: Fresh From Middle East Victory, Trump Sets His Sights on Peace in Ukraine
item.description: Pressure on Hamas worked for Gaza, but ahead of President Zelensky’s visit to the White House on Friday, Trump has yet to fully ramp up pressure on Russia.
item.dc:creator: Ian Lovett

item.title: Trump Declares Gaza War Over During Middle East Victory Lap
item.description: The president called on Israel and Arab governments to move beyond decades of conflict and war, but he faces obstacles extending the Gaza deal to the wider region.
item.dc:creator: Shayndi Raice

item.title: Opinion | What I Saw in Gaza in the Final Days of War
item.description: Israelis weren’t celebrating vengeance. They were relishing the prospect of peace, security and the end of a nightmare.

item.title: What to Know About the Gaza Deal
item.description: All remaining living hostages were released by Hamas, but key issues still need to be resolved in a subsequent phase of the agreement.
item.dc:creator: Michael R. Gordon

item.title: Dutch Government Takes Control of Chip Maker From Chinese Parent
item.description: In a “highly exceptional” move, the Dutch government wrested power of Netherlands-based Nexperia from owner Wingtech, citing risks to economic security.
item.dc:creator: Raffaele Huang

item.title: Frozen in Time Since Hamas Attacked, a Kibbutz Awaits Hostages Living and Dead
item.description: A quarter of Nir Oz’s population was either killed or kidnapped by the militant group on Oct. 7, 2023.
item.dc:creator: Feliz Solomon

item.title: China’s Exports Rise at Fastest Pace in Six Months Despite U.S. Tariffs
item.description: China’s exports rose at the fastest pace in six months in September, beating market expectations and underscoring the sector’s continued role as a key growth driver for the world’s second-largest economy.

item.title: Trump’s Fresh Tariff Assault Threatens China’s Fragile Economy
item.description: Beijing was already seeing growth slow before Trump announced the latest 100% tariff increase, part of a trade-war flare-up that China has blamed on the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Yoko Kubota

item.title: As Russian Aggression Turns West, Poland Says It’s Ready
item.description: For more than a decade, Poland has been building up for the worst-case scenario: becoming the front line in a war between Russia and the West.
item.dc:creator: Karolina Jeznach

item.title: China Detains Prominent Underground Pastor, Drawing Rebuke From U.S.
item.description: Ezra Jin, who built a vibrant church network spanning 40 cities across China, has faced years of intense pressure from authorities.
item.dc:creator: Brian Spegele

item.title: Trump May Send Tomahawks to Ukraine
item.description: The U.S. president threatens to send the long-range missiles to Kyiv if the war doesn’t end soon.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Andrews

item.title: South Korea Ordered 12 New Vessels from a U.S. Shipyard. Now Comes the Hard Part.
item.description: Hanwha has said two ships on order will be made almost entirely in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Costas Paris

item.title: Israel Prepares to Receive Its Last Living Hostages Held by Hamas
item.description: The militant group and Israel are preparing for captives to be released as early as Sunday, though Israel said it expects the handover to take place Monday morning.
item.dc:creator: Dov Lieber

item.title: A Coordinated Squeeze Forced Hamas to Accept a Deal It Didn’t Want
item.description: Under pressure from its overseas hosts and increasingly reviled at home, the militant group had little choice but to relent.
item.dc:creator: Summer Said

item.title: To Tackle a Baby Shortage, Tokyo Tries Easing the Pain of Childbirth
item.description: The Japanese capital is rolling out subsidies for epidurals in a country where cost is a barrier and women are often encouraged to endure the pain of delivery.
item.dc:creator: Junko Fukutome

item.title: Inside the West’s Race to Defend the Arctic
item.description: Sailors scanned for icebergs on a nine-day journey to the U.S.’s northernmost military installation this summer—part of an effort to erode Russia’s vast advantage in the region.
item.dc:creator: Sune Engel Rasmussen

item.title: Witkoff and Kushner Visit Gaza as Hamas Moves to Reassert Control
item.description: The U.S. is preparing to establish a center in Israel that will monitor the cease-fire and oversee the distribution of humanitarian aid.
item.dc:creator: Michael R. Gordon

item.title: Soldiers, Brothers, Music Lovers: The Israeli Hostages Expected Home From Gaza
item.description: The deal to halt the war after more than two years means 48 remaining hostages, living and dead, likely will soon be released.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Dangoor

item.title: Jared Kushner Is Back, and His Imprint Is All Over the Gaza Deal
item.description: The man who had sworn off any formal role in President Trump’s second term has been at the center of every decision leading up to the breakthrough agreement between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Brian Schwartz

item.title: North Korea’s Kim Flaunts New ICBM Able to Reach U.S.
item.description: The country’s leader challenged the West with an unapologetic military parade, including the unveiling of the “Hwasong-20” long-range missile, alongside guests from China and Russia.
item.dc:creator: Dasl Yoon

item.title: The American Troops Tasked With Helping Secure Gaza’s Future
item.description: A stabilization force will run alongside efforts to form a governing apparatus for the enclave.
item.dc:creator: Summer Said

item.title: Four Things to Know About Beijing’s Rare-Earths Bombshell
item.description: Ahead of a potential meeting between President Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping, Beijing dropped a bombshell: China was further restricting access to the indispensable tech materials.
item.dc:creator: Jon Emont

item.title: Trump to Hit China With Additional 100% Tariff, Citing Restrictions on Rare-Earth Elements
item.description: The president also said he would impose new export controls on critical software products in response to Beijing’s moves.
item.dc:creator: Brian Schwartz

item.title: Canadian Pensions Might Need to Invest More Domestically, Official Says
item.description: Industry minister Melanie Joly says talks are under way with pensions to redirect more of their US$2.1 trillion in assets into Canada.
item.dc:creator: Vipal Monga

item.title: Macron Reappoints Prime Minister Who Just Quit
item.description: The reappointment of Sébastien Lecornu highlights the French president’s dwindling options and stokes fears of continued political paralysis in France.
item.dc:creator: Sam Schechner

item.title: Canada’s Bank Supervisor to Propose Easing of Financial-Stability Rules
item.description: Banks argue that the strengthened capital buffers, introduced after the 2008-09 financial crisis, are unnecessary, the official said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: Melania Trump Says ‘Back Channel’ With Putin Led to Return of Ukrainian Children
item.description: The first lady said she has been in contact with the Russian leader since sending him a letter in August expressing concern for abducted children.
item.dc:creator: Meridith McGraw

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize Awarded to Venezuelan Opposition Leader María Corina Machado
item.description: The accolade was awarded to the opposition leader for her work promoting democracy and fighting dictatorship in the country.
item.dc:creator: Kejal Vyas

item.title: Canada, U.S. Have Discussed Reviving Keystone XL
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney said he and President Trump have discussed the development of energy projects that would help both countries, including the twice-rejected Keystone XL expansion project.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: The 11th-Hour Campaign to Land Trump a Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: A bid was mounted to persuade the Nobel committee to make Trump the fifth American president to receive the honor.
item.dc:creator: Brett Forrest

item.title: Microsoft, Anthropic Hire Former British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak
item.description: Sunak, who remains a member of Britain’s parliament, said he would be working with the tech companies as a senior adviser and strategic consultant.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Look

item.title: Peru Removes Unpopular President Amid Anger Over Crime
item.description: Peru’s Congress ousted President Dina Boluarte from power in the latest round of political turmoil in the Andean nation.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Dubé

item.title: Putin Admits Russia’s Role in Downing Azerbaijani Passenger Jet
item.description: The incident last year further eroded Moscow’s influence across the former Soviet states.
item.dc:creator: Georgi Kantchev

item.title: BOE Must Keep Key Rate Restrictive to Boost Growth, Mann Says
item.description: The Bank of England should keep its key rate high so as to foster conditions for future growth, rate-setter Catherine L. Mann said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Cash-Strapped U.K. Discovers Missing $4 Billion Thanks to Data Flub
item.description: Even after the revision, public borrowing is above projections made earlier this year by the government’s budget watchdog.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: International Criminal Court Convicts Sudanese Militia Leader of War Crimes
item.description: The guilty finding is a rare conviction for the court, and comes as the institution confronts U.S. sanctions and sexual-assault allegations.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Dalton

item.title: Trump Praises Putin’s Offer to Extend Nuclear Treaty
item.description: An accord capping the number of long-range nuclear weapons was due to expire in February but would be extended by a year.
item.dc:creator: Michael R. Gordon

item.title: Putin Warns West as Drones Appear in European Skies
item.description: The Russian leader says that Moscow is ready to respond to NATO efforts to boost support for Ukraine in the war.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Grove

item.title: Man Killed in U.K. Synagogue Attack Was Accidentally Shot by Police
item.description: One of those killed and one injured were hit by gunfire from officers who were trying to stop the attacker from entering the synagogue, police said.
item.dc:creator: David Luhnow

item.title: Who Is Sarah Mullally, the Anglican Church’s First Female Leader?
item.description: She has been named the first female Archbishop of Canterbury in the church’s nearly 500-year history. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Max Colchester

item.title: France Detains Russian ‘Shadow Fleet’ Tanker Suspected in Drone Attack
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron said authorities are investigating incursions into Danish airspace that rattled NATO allies.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Dalton

item.title: German Firm’s African Green-Energy Project Runs Into Ghosts From Past
item.description: Namibia’s indigenous Nama population argues they have been sidelined in a $10 billion project being built on their ancestral lands.
item.dc:creator: Caroline Kimeu

item.title: Powerful Earthquake Kills at Least 69 People in Central Philippines
item.description: The Philippines sits in the so-called Ring of Fire, a seismic arc of volcanoes and fault lines around the Pacific basin.
item.dc:creator: Gabriele Steinhauser

item.title: Russia’s Ambitious Plans in Africa Are Unraveling
item.description: Not long ago a rising military force in Africa, Russia is now struggling to maintain its footprint on the continent.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: Rwanda’s President Turns to Sport to Give Tarnished Image a Makeover
item.description: Paul Kagame hopes to bring Formula One to a country accused of using rebels to take critical minerals from its neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: The Path to the American Dream Is Narrowing for Indian Tech Workers
item.description: About 70% of H-1B visas go to Indians. Looming changes to the program are upending plans, but may help India retain talent.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: The Race Back to America for a Plane Full of H-1B Workers
item.description: Reports of a new visa fee for foreign workers prompted hasty goodbyes, races to the airport and an anxiety-filled flight to San Francisco.
item.dc:creator: Robert McMillan

item.title: Setting Up a Business in India Is Hard. Leaving Is Even Harder.
item.description: General Motors ran into barriers on its way out of India, highlighting the hurdles that keep foreign companies leery of doing business there.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: It Was a Failing Temple. Then It Started Offering God’s Help in Getting a Visa.
item.description: Indians with American dreams flock to this place of worship, which touts its power to summon divine assistance with bureaucratic hurdles.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: Modi’s Strategy for Mending Ties With Trump: a Stiff Upper Lip
item.description: India’s prime minister has maintained a stoic silence in the face of sharp comments from Trump, while signaling he is eager to stay friends.
item.dc:creator: Robbie Gramer

item.title: Pentagon Review of Aukus Security Pact Worries U.K., Australia
item.description: The review throws into doubt a strategic partnership that aims to give Australia nuclear-powered submarines and deter Chinese aggression in the Indo-Pacific.
item.dc:creator: Rhiannon Hoyle

item.title: The Best Travel Shoes to Make Every Trip Lighter and Easier
item.description: No matter the destination, these shoes will get you there.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Selinger

item.title: The Best Laptop Backpacks, According to CEOs, Pilots and Stylists
item.description: From commuting to long-haul flights, these are the bags avid travelers rely on for their trips.
item.dc:creator: Sal Vaglica

item.title: Best of Buy Side Awards 2025: Travel
item.description: Tried and tested by our expert travel writers and editors, these Buy Side best product award-winning luggage picks will ensure your trip gets off to a great start.
item.dc:creator: Nick Guy

item.title: Russia’s Side Quest to Dominate Africa: Hijack a Videogame
item.description: Players in the ‘African Dawn’ videogame are asked to choose a side aligned with either Russia or the West.
item.dc:creator: Sarah E. Needleman

item.title: Families Battle Tech Giants as Australia Pushes for an Under-16 Social-Media Ban
item.description: The proposal marks the latest effort by political leaders worldwide to regulate children’s use of platforms, amid concerns that it is harming their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: ‘We’ve Got to Kill’: Inside New Zealand’s Mission to Wipe Out Predators
item.description: Scientists debate whether a multibillion-dollar plan to eliminate invasive animals by 2050 is feasible.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: New Zealand’s Economy Emerges From Recession in First Quarter
item.description: New Zealand’s farm-rich economy returned to growth in the first quarter, exiting the recession that has dogged it for much of last year, but further weakness can’t be ruled out.
item.dc:creator: Rthvika Suvarna
